content.content:
1→# Undocumented Features
     2→
     3→Features mentioned in Claude Code release notes but not yet covered in official documentation. Information is based on release note descriptions and observed behavior. Details may be incomplete or subject to change.
     4→
     5→**Latest Release**: v2.1.31
     6→
     7→---
     8→
     9→## Real-time Thinking in Transcript Mode
    10→
    11→**What it is**: Show thinking blocks in real-time when verbose output is enabled
    12→
    13→**Introduced**: v2.1.0
    14→
    15→**What we know**:
    16→- Ctrl+O verbose/transcript mode now shows thinking blocks as they stream
    17→- Previously thinking blocks only appeared after completion
    18→- Enables watching Claude's reasoning process in real-time
    19→- Useful for understanding complex decision-making
    20→
    21→---
    22→
    23→## Permission Prompt Feedback
    24→
    25→**What it is**: Ability to provide feedback when accepting permission prompts
    26→
    27→**Introduced**: v2.1.7
    28→
    29→**What we know**:
    30→- Users can now provide feedback when accepting permission prompts
    31→- Helps improve permission system based on user experience
    32→- Likely integrated into permission dialog UI
    33→
    34→**Use cases**:
    35→- Report overly restrictive permissions
    36→- Suggest better permission defaults
    37→- Help Anthropic improve permission UX
    38→
    39→---
    40→
    41→## Agent Final Response in Task Notifications
    42→
    43→**What it is**: Display of agent's final response inline in task completion notifications
    44→
    45→**Introduced**: v2.1.7
    46→
    47→**What we know**:
    48→- Task notifications now show the agent's final response inline
    49→- Provides context without needing to check task details separately
    50→- Improves visibility into what agents accomplished
    51→
    52→**Expected behavior**:
    53→- Background task completes
    54→- Notification shows both completion status and agent's summary
    55→- Reduces need to navigate to task details
    56→
    57→---
    58→
    59→## OAuth/API Console URL Update
    60→
    61→**What it is**: URL change for OAuth and API Console from anthropic.com to platform.claude.com
    62→
    63→**Introduced**: v2.1.7
    64→
    65→**What we know**:
    66→- OAuth and API Console URLs now point to platform.claude.com
    67→- Previously used anthropic.com domain
    68→- Likely part of infrastructure consolidation
    69→
    70→**Updated URLs**:
    71→- OAuth: platform.claude.com/oauth
    72→- API Console: platform.claude.com/console
    73→
    74→---
    75→
    76→## Session URL Attribution in Git
    77→
    78→**What it is**: Automatic attribution of session URLs to commits and PRs from web sessions
    79→
    80→**Introduced**: v2.1.9
    81→
    82→**What we know**:
    83→- Web sessions now add session URL attribution to commits and PRs
    84→- Helps trace git activity back to originating web session
    85→- Improves audit trail for web-based workflows
    86→
    87→**Expected format**:
    88→- Commit/PR includes URL to originating claude.ai session
    89→- Enables jumping from git history to conversation context
    90→
    91→---
    92→
    93→## Copy OAuth URL Keyboard Shortcut
    94→
    95→**What it is**: Keyboard shortcut 'c' to copy OAuth URL when browser doesn't open during login
    96→
    97→**Introduced**: v2.1.10
    98→
    99→**What we know**:
   100→- Press 'c' to copy OAuth URL to clipboard during login
   101→- Useful when browser auto-open fails
   102→- Improves login experience in restricted environments
   103→
   104→**Expected workflow**:
   105→1. Start login process
   106→2. Browser fails to open automatically
   107→3. Press 'c' to copy URL to clipboard
   108→4. Paste URL manually in browser
   109→
   110→---
   111→
   112→## Trust Warning for Plugin Installation in VSCode
   113→
   114→**What it is**: Warning dialog when installing plugins via VSCode extension
   115→
   116→**Introduced**: v2.1.10
   117→
   118→**What we know**:
   119→- VSCode extension shows trust warning before plugin installation
   120→- Improves security awareness when adding third-party plugins
   121→- Aligns with VSCode security best practices
   122→
   123→---
   124→
   125→## Startup Keystroke Capture Improvement
   126→
   127→**What it is**: Enhanced startup to capture keystrokes before REPL is fully ready
   128→
   129→**Introduced**: v2.1.10
   130→
   131→**What we know**:
   132→- Startup improved to capture keystrokes earlier
   133→- Prevents lost input during Claude Code initialization
   134→- Improves responsiveness during startup phase
   135→
   136→**Benefits**:
   137→- No need to wait for full REPL readiness before typing
   138→- Faster perceived startup time
   139→- Better user experience for quick commands
   140→
   141→---
   142→
   143→## File Suggestions as Removable Attachments
   144→
   145→**What it is**: Enhanced display of file suggestions as removable attachments in the UI
   146→
   147→**Introduced**: v2.1.10
   148→
   149→**What we know**:
   150→- File suggestions now display as removable attachments
   151→- Improves clarity of which files are included in context
   152→- Allows easy removal before sending prompt
   153→
   154→**Expected behavior**:
   155→- Suggest files with @-mention
   156→- Files appear as attachment chips
   157→- Click to remove unwanted suggestions before submit
   158→
   159→---
   160→
   161→## Per-User Temp Directory Isolation
   162→
   163→**What it is**: Isolated temporary directories for each user to prevent permission conflicts
   164→
   165→**Introduced**: v2.1.23
   166→
   167→**What we know**:
   168→- Fixed per-user temp directory isolation preventing permission conflicts on shared systems
   169→- Each user gets their own isolated temp directory
   170→- Prevents conflicts when multiple users run Claude Code on same system
   171→
   172→---
   173→
   174→## Bash Timeout Duration Display
   175→
   176→**What it is**: Display of timeout duration alongside elapsed time for Bash commands
   177→
   178→**Introduced**: v2.1.23
   179→
   180→**What we know**:
   181→- Bash commands now display timeout duration alongside elapsed time
   182→- Provides visibility into how long until a command times out
   183→- Helps users understand command execution constraints
   184→
   185→---
   186→
   187→## /debug command
   188→
   189→**What it is**: Added /debug for Claude to help troubleshoot the current session
   190→
   191→**Introduced**: v2.1.30
   192→
   193→**What we know**:
   194→- Available in interactive mode for session troubleshooting
   195→- Helps Claude analyze current session state
   196→- Useful for debugging complex issues or session state problems
   197→
   198→---
   199→
   200→## Token count, tool uses, and duration metrics to Task tool results
   201→
   202→**What it is**: Added token count, tool uses, and duration metrics to Task tool results
   203→
   204→**Introduced**: v2.1.30
   205→
   206→**What we know**:
   207→- Task tool results now include token usage statistics
   208→- Shows number of tool invocations during task execution
   209→- Displays duration of task execution
   210→- Enables cost and performance analysis of background tasks
   211→
   212→**Use cases**:
   213→- Monitor subagent efficiency and resource usage
   214→- Understand performance characteristics of tasks
   215→- Track token consumption for cost management
   216→
   217→---
   218→
   219→## Reduced motion mode
   220→
   221→**What it is**: Added reduced motion mode to the config
   222→
   223→**Introduced**: v2.1.30
   224→
   225→**What we know**:
   226→- New configuration setting to reduce animations and visual motion
   227→- Improves accessibility for users sensitive to motion
   228→- Follows system accessibility preferences
   229→- Reduces visual strain during extended sessions
   230→
   231→---
   232→
   233→## TaskStop tool result improvement
   234→
   235→**What it is**: Improved TaskStop tool to display the stopped command/task description in the result line instead of a generic 'Task stopped' message
   236→
   237→**Introduced**: v2.1.30
   238→
   239→**What we know**:
   240→- TaskStop results now show the specific task that was stopped
   241→- Provides better feedback about which background task was terminated
   242→- Clearer output when managing multiple background tasks
   243→
   244→

content.content:
1→# Core Features
     2→
     3→Foundational Claude Code capabilities that enable extensibility and customization.
     4→
     5→**Last updated**: 2026-02-01
     6→
     7→---
     8→
     9→## Claude Code Overview
    10→
    11→**What it is**: High-level overview of Claude Code's core capabilities, characteristics, and setup requirements
    12→
    13→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/overview
    14→
    15→**Key concepts**:
    16→- **Core capabilities**: Build features (natural language to code), debug and fix issues, codebase navigation, automation (lint fixes, merge conflicts, release notes)
    17→- **Terminal-native**: Integrates into existing developer workflows, not a separate IDE
    18→- **Direct action**: Can edit files, execute commands, create commits directly
    19→- **MCP integration**: Access external resources (Google Drive, Figma, Slack) through Model Context Protocol
    20→- **Unix philosophy**: Composable, scriptable, pipeable for CI/CD integration
    21→- **Enterprise ready**: Available via Claude API, AWS Bedrock, Google Vertex AI with security/privacy/compliance
    22→- **VS Code extension (Beta)**: Graphical IDE alternative without terminal requirements
    23→- **Setup**: Requires Node.js 18+, install via `npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code`
    24→
    25→---
    26→
    27→## Skills (Unified with Slash Commands)
    28→
    29→**What it is**: The extensibility system for Claude Code. Skills are SKILL.md files with YAML frontmatter that extend Claude's capabilities. Custom slash commands have been merged into skills - both `.claude/commands/review.md` and `.claude/skills/review/SKILL.md` create `/review` and work the same way.
    30→
    31→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/skills
    32→
    33→**Key concepts**:
    34→- **Dual invocation model**: Skills can be invoked by users (`/skill-name`) OR by Claude automatically when relevant. Both modes enabled by default.
    35→- **User invocation**: Type `/skill-name` to invoke directly; skills appear in slash command autocomplete menu
    36→- **Model invocation**: Claude loads skills automatically when conversation matches the description field
    37→- **Invocation control**: `disable-model-invocation: true` prevents Claude from auto-loading (user-only); `user-invocable: false` hides from menu (Claude-only)
    38→- **Backwards compatibility**: Files in `.claude/commands/` still work with same frontmatter support; if skill and command share a name, skill takes precedence
    39→- **Multi-file structure**: SKILL.md (required) + optional supporting files (references/, scripts/, templates/); manages context efficiently
    40→- **Three scopes**: Personal (`~/.claude/skills/`), Project (`.claude/skills/`, git-shared), Plugin (bundled with Claude Code plugins)
    41→- **Enterprise scope**: Organization-wide skills via managed settings
    42→- **Nested directory discovery**: Skills auto-discovered from nested `.claude/skills/` directories; supports monorepo setups
    43→- **Tool restrictions**: `allowed-tools` frontmatter field limits available tools within skill for security/safety
    44→- **Description field is critical**: Must be specific with trigger terms for discoverability (max 1024 characters); tells Claude when to auto-load
    45→- **Supporting files**: `scripts/` (executable code), `references/` (docs loaded as needed), `assets/` (files used in output)
    46→- **Argument passing**: `$ARGUMENTS` for all args, `$0`/`$1`/`$2` shorthand, `${CLAUDE_SESSION_ID}` for session ID; if `$ARGUMENTS` not in content, args appended automatically
    47→- **Dynamic context**: `!`command`` syntax runs shell commands before skill content is sent to Claude; output replaces placeholder
    48→- **Sharing**: Via plugins (recommended, marketplace distribution) or project repository (`.claude/skills/`, team auto-gets on pull)
    49→- **Subagent pairing**: Skills naturally pair with subagents for context protection. Two patterns:
    50→  - `agent: <agent-name>` spawns subagent with skill loaded into fresh context (ideal for search/research skills using Explore agent)
    51→  - `context: fork` spawns subagent with current conversation context carried over (ideal for parallel operations like memory/summarization that shouldn't pollute main context)
    52→- **Subagent skill loading**: Subagents can auto-load specific skills via `skills` frontmatter field; skills unload when subagent completes
    53→- **Hot-reload**: Skills automatically reloaded when created or modified, no restart required
    54→- **Skill hooks**: Skills can define hooks scoped to their lifecycle using `hooks` frontmatter field; supports `PreToolUse`, `PostToolUse`, and `Stop` events
    55→- **Once hooks**: Hooks with `once: true` run only once per session, then are removed
    56→- **Permission-free skills**: Skills without additional permissions or hooks load without requiring user approval; reduces friction for simple skills
    57→- **Unified Skill tool**: Claude invokes skills programmatically via `Skill` tool; control access via `/permissions` rules like `Skill(name)` or `Skill(name:*)`
    58→
    59→---
    60→
    61→## MCP (Model Context Protocol) Servers
    62→
    63→**What it is**: Open-source standard for AI-tool integrations enabling Claude Code to access external tools, databases, and APIs (hundreds of third-party services)
    64→
    65→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/mcp
    66→
    67→**Key concepts**:
    68→- **Core capabilities**: Retrieve features from issue trackers, analyze monitoring data, query databases, access design files, automate workflows
    69→- **Three transport types**: HTTP (recommended for cloud services), SSE (deprecated but functional), Stdio (local processes for custom scripts)
    70→- **Three scopes**: Local (default, personal project configs), Project (team-shared via `.mcp.json` in version control), User (cross-project personal utilities)
    71→- **Scope precedence**: Local overrides project and user when naming conflicts occur
    72→- **Popular integrations**: Sentry, Hugging Face, Jam, Asana, Jira, Linear, Notion, Airtable, HubSpot, PostgreSQL, Stripe, Square, PayPal
    73→- **Management commands**: `claude mcp list/get/remove`, `/mcp` within Claude Code
    74→- **Authentication**: OAuth 2.0 automatic for HTTP servers, tokens stored securely and auto-refreshed
    75→- **Enterprise**: System-wide `managed-mcp.json` for standardization, allowlists/denylists for control
    76→- **Tool naming**: MCP tools use pattern `mcp__<server-name>__<tool-name>`
    77→- **Dynamic updates**: MCP `list_changed` notifications allow servers to dynamically update available tools, prompts, and resources without reconnecting
    78→- **structuredContent support**: MCP servers can return `structuredContent` field in tool responses for richer outputs beyond plain text (formatting, hierarchy, structured data)
    79→- **headersHelper**: Dynamic header generation via helper script in MCP config; script outputs JSON with header key-value pairs; enables OAuth token refresh and short-lived API keys
    80→
    81→---
    82→
    83→## Plugins
    84→
    85→**What it is**: Extensions that add custom functionality (commands, agents, skills, hooks, MCP servers) that can be shared across projects and teams
    86→
    87→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/plugins
    88→
    89→**Key concepts**:
    90→- **Components**: Skills (extensibility, includes legacy commands), Agents (specialized AI assistants), Hooks (event handlers), MCP Servers (external integrations)
    91→- **Structure**: `.claude-plugin/plugin.json` (metadata), `skills/`, `agents/`, `hooks/` directories (legacy `commands/` still supported)
    92→- **Installation**: `/plugin` interactive menu (browse/discover), direct commands (`install/enable/disable`)
    93→- **Marketplaces**: Catalogs of plugins, add via `/plugin marketplace add your-org/claude-plugins`
    94→- **Team configuration**: Automatic installation via `.claude/settings.json` in repository
    95→- **Development**: Create plugin.json, add components, test locally, distribute through catalogs
    96→- **Best practices**: Semantic versioning, comprehensive README, local testing, organize by functionality
    97→- **User roles**: Plugin users (discover/install), Developers (create/distribute), Team leaders (governance/catalogs)
    98→- **Search in installed list**: Type to filter plugins by name or description in the Installed tab
    99→- **Auto-updates**: Toggle per marketplace; official marketplaces auto-update by default
   100→- **SHA pinning**: Pin plugins to specific git commit SHAs for exact version control; use `sha` field in marketplace entry for reproducible builds; useful for enterprise audit trails
   101→
   102→---
   103→
   104→## Agents and Subagents
   105→
   106→**What it is**: Specialized AI assistants that Claude Code can delegate tasks to. Each operates with its own separate context window and can be configured with specific system prompts, tools, and models for task-specific problem-solving.
   107→
   108→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/sub-agents
   109→
   110→**Key concepts**:
   111→- **Benefits**: Context preservation (separate windows prevent main conversation pollution), specialized expertise (fine-tuned instructions), reusability (work across projects), flexible permissions (different tool access levels)
   112→- **Creation**: `/agents` then Create New Agent then Choose scope then Define/customize then Select tools then Save; or manually create Markdown files with YAML frontmatter
   113→- **File structure**: YAML frontmatter with `name` (required, lowercase-hyphenated), `description` (required, natural language purpose), `tools` (optional, comma-separated), `model` (optional, sonnet/opus/haiku/inherit), `disallowedTools` (optional, explicit tool blocking), `permissionMode` (optional, permission behavior for specific agent)
   114→- **File locations** (priority order): Project (`.claude/agents/`, highest), CLI flag (`--agents`, add subagents dynamically), User (`~/.claude/agents/`, lower), Plugin (`agents/` directory)
   115→- **Usage**: Automatic delegation (Claude proactively identifies based on descriptions; use "PROACTIVELY" or "MUST BE USED" in description), Explicit invocation (direct requests to use specific subagent), @-mention support with typeahead
   116→- **Tool access**: Inherits all tools if not specified; can restrict to specific tools via `tools` field; can explicitly block tools via `disallowedTools` field; includes MCP server tools
   117→- **Skill auto-loading**: `skills` frontmatter field loads specific skills when subagent activates; enables specialized knowledge per subagent; skills unload when subagent completes
   118→- **Built-in subagents**: Explore (Haiku-powered read-only codebase exploration with thoroughness levels: quick/medium/very thorough), Plan (automatic codebase research during plan mode using Read/Glob/Grep/Bash tools with Sonnet model, prevents infinite nesting), General-purpose (complex multi-step tasks with all tools), Helper agents (Bash, statusline-setup, Claude Code Guide)
   119→- **Best practices**: Start with Claude-generated then customize, design focused subagents with single responsibilities, write detailed prompts with constraints, limit tool access to necessary only, version control project subagents
   120→- **Advanced**: Chaining (multiple sequential subagents), dynamic selection (Claude intelligently chooses), model selection ('inherit' for consistency), subagent resumption (Claude can resume previous subagents), dynamic model choice (Claude selects model for subagent tasks)
   121→- **Agent hooks**: Agents can define hooks in frontmatter using `hooks` field; supports `PreToolUse`, `PostToolUse`, and `Stop` events
   122→- **Disable via Task tool**: Use `Task(AgentName)` syntax in permission deny rules to prevent specific agents from being invoked
   123→- **Permission modes**: `permissionMode` field controls permission behavior per agent (`default`, `acceptEdits`, `dontAsk`, `bypassPermissions`, `plan`)
   124→- **Background execution**: Agents can run in foreground (blocking with permission passthrough) or background (concurrent with auto-deny for missing permissions); MCP tools not available in background
   125→
   126→---
   127→
   128→## Built-in Commands
   129→
   130→**What it is**: Claude Code's built-in slash commands for session management, configuration, and common operations. For custom commands, see Skills section above.
   131→
   132→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/interactive-mode#built-in-commands
   133→
   134→**Key concepts**:
   135→- **Session commands**: `/clear` (history), `/resume` (resume by name or ID), `/rename` (name session), `/teleport` (resume remote session)
   136→- **Configuration**: `/config` (settings with search), `/model` (selection), `/permissions` (tool access), `/keybindings` (customize shortcuts)
   137→- **Context management**: `/memory` (CLAUDE.md editing), `/compact` (reduce context), `/cost` (token usage), `/stats` (usage statistics)
   138→- **Tools**: `/mcp` (server management), `/sandbox` (sandboxed bash), `/todos` (view task list), `/plan` (enter plan mode)
   139→- **Help**: `/help` (usage), `/context` (view loaded context)
   140→- **Remote**: `/remote-env` (configure remote environment)
   141→- **MCP prompts**: Format `mcp__<server-name>__<prompt-name>` from MCP server prompts
   142→- **Autocomplete**: Works at any position in input, not just at the beginning
   143→- **Note**: Custom slash commands (`.claude/commands/`) have been merged into the Skills system; existing command files continue to work
   144→
   145→---
   146→
   147→## Hooks
   148→
   149→**What it is**: Automated bash scripts that execute in response to specific events during Claude Code sessions, enabling custom automation, validation, and integration workflows
   150→
   151→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/hooks
   152→
   153→**Key concepts**:
   154→- **Execution model**: All matching hooks run in parallel with 60-second default timeout; receive JSON via stdin, return structured output to control Claude
   155→- **Configuration locations**: `~/.claude/settings.json` (user), `.claude/settings.json` (project), `.claude/settings.local.json` (local project), enterprise managed policy, skill/agent/command frontmatter
   156→- **11 event types**: PreToolUse (before tool execution, can modify tool inputs), PostToolUse (after completion), UserPromptSubmit (prompt submission), Notification (permission requests with matcher values for event filtering), PermissionRequest (automatically approve/deny tool permissions), Stop (main agent finish, prompt-based matching), SubagentStart (subagent begins), SubagentStop (subagent finish), SessionStart (session begins), SessionEnd (session terminates), PreCompact (before context compacting), Setup (triggered via CLI flags)
   157→- **Setup hook**: Triggered via `--init`, `--init-only`, or `--maintenance` CLI flags; runs setup scripts for repository initialization, dependency installation, or maintenance tasks before the interactive session starts
   158→- **Matcher patterns**: Exact (`Write`), regex (`Edit|Write`), wildcard (`*`), prompt-based (Stop hooks can match against user prompts), Notification and PermissionRequest matcher values for event-specific filtering; case-sensitive
   159→- **Exit codes**: 0 (success, stdout to transcript), 2 (blocking error, stderr to Claude), other (non-blocking error, stderr to user)
   160→- **JSON output**: Advanced control with `continue`, `decision`, `reason`, and hook-specific parameters
   161→- **PreToolUse advanced features**:
   162→  - **updatedInput parameter**: Allows modifying tool input parameters before execution; returned in JSON output to override original tool inputs
   163→  - **ask parameter**: Triggers user confirmation dialog during hook execution; use in JSON output to prompt for approval before tool proceeds
   164→  - **additionalContext parameter**: Adds context string to Claude before tool executes; returned in `hookSpecificOutput.additionalContext` field
   165→- **Hook input fields**: `tool_use_id` field in PreToolUse and PostToolUse hooks enables correlation between pre/post events for same tool call
   166→- **PermissionRequest hook**: Runs when user shown permission dialog; use decision control to allow/deny automatically; recognizes same matcher values as PreToolUse
   167→- **Environment variables**: `CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR` (project root path), `CLAUDE_ENV_FILE` (SessionStart persistence), `CLAUDE_CODE_REMOTE` (remote/local indicator)
   168→- **Security warning**: Execute arbitrary shell commands automatically - validate/sanitize input, quote variables, use absolute paths, avoid sensitive files, test in safe environments
   169→- **MCP integration**: Works with MCP tools using pattern `mcp__<server>__<tool>`
   170→- **Debugging**: Use `claude --debug` for execution details, matched commands, exit codes, output
   171→- **Component hooks**: Skills, agents, and slash commands can define hooks in frontmatter; scoped to component lifecycle
   172→- **Once hooks**: `once: true` option runs hook only once per session for skills and commands
   173→- **Prompt-based hooks**: `type: "prompt"` uses LLM to evaluate context; supported for Stop, SubagentStop, and other events
   174→
   175→---
   176→
   177→## Task Tool
   178→
   179→**What it is**: Core tool allowing Claude to delegate work to specialized subagents with isolated contexts
   180→
   181→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/sub-agents
   182→
   183→**Key concepts**:
   184→- **Purpose**: Invoke subagents for specialized tasks while preserving main conversation context
   185→- **Context isolation**: Each subagent operates with separate context window, preventing pollution of main conversation
   186→- **Automatic selection**: Claude proactively identifies appropriate subagent based on task and descriptions
   187→- **Explicit invocation**: Users can request specific subagent directly
   188→- **Tool inheritance**: Subagents inherit or restrict tool access based on configuration
   189→- **Result integration**: Subagent work summarized and returned to main conversation
   190→- **Chaining support**: Multiple subagents can work sequentially on complex tasks
   191→- **Permission control**: Can be disabled via `/permissions` or blocked with `Task(AgentName)` syntax for specific agents
   192→
   193→---
   194→
   195→## AskUserQuestion Tool
   196→
   197→**What it is**: Interactive tool for asking structured multiple-choice questions during conversations
   198→
   199→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/settings (Tools Available to Claude table)
   200→
   201→**Key concepts**:
   202→- **Purpose**: Enables Claude to ask structured questions with multiple-choice options
   203→- **Features**: Single-select or multi-select modes, automatic "Other" option for custom input
   204→- **Use cases**: Gathering preferences, clarifying ambiguous requirements, plan mode decisions
   205→- **Question structure**: Header (short label), question text, 2-4 options with label and description
   206→- **Behavioral constraints**: 60-second timeout, 1-4 questions per call, not available in subagents spawned via Task tool
   207→- **Permission**: No permission required for this tool
   208→- **Ctrl+G support**: External editor (Ctrl+G) now works in AskUserQuestion input field for composing longer responses
   209→
   210→---
   211→
   212→## LSP Tool
   213→
   214→**What it is**: Language Server Protocol integration for semantic code intelligence
   215→
   216→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/settings (Tools Available to Claude table)
   217→
   218→**Key concepts**:
   219→- **Introduced**: v2.0.74 (2025-12)
   220→- **Purpose**: Semantic code understanding beyond grep - go-to-definition, find references, hover documentation/types
   221→- **Benefits**: More accurate than grep, understands code structure and types
   222→- **Capabilities**: Navigate code definitions, find all references to symbols, get type information and documentation
   223→- **Use cases**: Codebase exploration, refactoring support, understanding code relationships
   224→- **Likely supported languages**: TypeScript/JavaScript, Python, other LSP-compatible languages
   225→
   226→

content.content:
1→# Configuration
     2→
     3→Settings, permissions, memory, and customization options for Claude Code.
     4→
     5→**Last updated**: 2026-02-01
     6→
     7→---
     8→
     9→## Memory Management (CLAUDE.md)
    10→
    11→**What it is**: System for retaining preferences, coding style, project conventions across sessions via memory files
    12→
    13→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory
    14→
    15→**Key concepts**:
    16→- **Memory hierarchy** (precedence order): Enterprise Policy (org-wide), Project Memory (`./CLAUDE.md` or `./.claude/CLAUDE.md`), User Memory (`~/.claude/CLAUDE.md`), Project Local (deprecated)
    17→- **Auto-loading**: Files loaded automatically on launch; recurses up from cwd to (but not including) root directory
    18→- **File imports**: `@path/to/file` syntax includes external docs; recursive up to 5 hops deep
    19→- **Quick addition**: Start input with `#` to rapidly add memories (prompts for location)
    20→- **Management**: `/memory` (edit in editor), `/init` (bootstrap CLAUDE.md for codebase)
    21→- **Best practices**: Be specific ("2-space indentation"), organize with markdown headings, review periodically as projects evolve
    22→
    23→---
    24→
    25→## Modular Rules (.claude/rules/)
    26→
    27→**What it is**: Organized, topic-specific instruction files that extend project memory with focused guidelines for code style, testing, security, and other conventions
    28→
    29→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory
    30→
    31→**Key concepts**:
    32→- **Directory structure**: Place `.md` files in `.claude/rules/` for automatic loading alongside `CLAUDE.md`
    33→- **Path-specific rules**: Use YAML frontmatter with `paths` field for conditional rules (e.g., `paths: src/api/**/*.ts`)
    34→- **Glob patterns**: Standard glob syntax including `**/*.ts`, `*.md`, braces `{ts,tsx}`, and multiple patterns
    35→- **Subdirectories**: Organize rules hierarchically (e.g., `frontend/`, `backend/`) - all `.md` files discovered recursively
    36→- **User-level rules**: Personal rules at `~/.claude/rules/` apply to all projects (lower priority than project rules)
    37→- **Symlinks supported**: Share common rules across projects via symlinks (circular symlinks handled gracefully)
    38→- **Best practices**: Keep rules focused (one topic per file), use descriptive filenames, use conditional paths sparingly, organize with subdirectories
    39→
    40→---
    41→
    42→## Model Configuration
    43→
    44→**What it is**: Model selection, aliasing, and behavior customization for different tasks and account types
    45→
    46→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/model-config
    47→
    48→**Key concepts**:
    49→- **Primary aliases**: `sonnet` (4.5, daily coding), `opus` (4.5, complex reasoning), `haiku` (4.5, fast tasks), `default` (recommended for account type)
    50→- **Special aliases**: `opusplan` (opus for plan mode, sonnet for execution), `sonnet[1m]` (million-token extended context)
    51→- **Configuration methods** (priority order): `/model <alias>` (mid-session), `claude --model <alias>` (startup), `ANTHROPIC_MODEL` (environment), settings.json (persistent)
    52→- **Environment variables**: ANTHROPIC_DEFAULT_OPUS_MODEL, ANTHROPIC_DEFAULT_SONNET_MODEL, ANTHROPIC_DEFAULT_HAIKU_MODEL, CLAUDE_CODE_SUBAGENT_MODEL
    53→- **Prompt caching**: DISABLE_PROMPT_CACHING variables (global overrides model-specific)
    54→- **Haiku 4.5**: Auto-uses Sonnet in plan mode (SonnetPlan behavior by default) for Pro users
    55→
    56→---
    57→
    58→## Permission Management
    59→
    60→**What it is**: Tool usage control through allow/ask/deny rules for security and workflow customization
    61→
    62→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings
    63→
    64→**Key concepts**:
    65→- **Three modes**: Allow (auto-approve), Ask (confirmation prompt), Deny (block tool use)
    66→- **Configuration**: settings.json at user (`~/.claude/`), project (`.claude/`, shared), or local (`.claude/settings.local.json`, personal)
    67→- **`/permissions` command**: Manage tool permissions interactively
    68→- **Rule format**: Array of permission rules per mode (e.g., `Bash(git push:*)`, `Read(./.env)`)
    69→- **Wildcard equivalence**: `Bash(*)` is treated as equivalent to `Bash` (matches all commands)
    70→- **Use cases**: Prevent dangerous operations, require confirmation for sensitive actions, enable autonomous work within boundaries
    71→- **MCP integration**: Works with MCP tools using pattern `mcp__<server>__<tool>`
    72→- **Wildcard MCP permissions**: Use `mcp__server__*` syntax to allow/deny all tools from a server
    73→- **Wildcard bash patterns**: Use patterns like `Bash(npm *)` to match commands with any arguments
    74→- **Unreachable rule warnings**: Claude Code warns when permission rules are unreachable due to precedence
    75→- **Task tool permissions**: Use `Task(AgentName)` syntax in deny rules to prevent specific agents from being invoked (cross-reference: core-features.md Agents section for agent configuration)
    76→
    77→---
    78→
    79→## Configuration Backup
    80→
    81→**What it is**: Automatic timestamped backups of configuration files with rotation
    82→
    83→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/settings
    84→
    85→**Key concepts**:
    86→- **Automatic backups**: Claude Code automatically creates timestamped backups of configuration files
    87→- **Retention**: Keeps the five most recent backups to prevent data loss
    88→- **Covered files**: settings.json, .claude.json, managed-settings.json
    89→- **Recovery**: Enables recovery from recent config mistakes without manual backup management
    90→
    91→---
    92→
    93→## Sandboxing
    94→
    95→**What it is**: Isolated execution environments using OS-level security primitives to restrict filesystem and network access
    96→
    97→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sandboxing
    98→
    99→**Key concepts**:
   100→- **Activation**: `/sandbox` command enables sandboxed bash with default settings
   101→- **Filesystem isolation**: Read/write limited to current working directory; read-only system access excluding denied directories; modifications outside cwd require permission
   102→- **Network isolation**: Access restricted to approved domains via proxy; new domain requests trigger confirmation; restrictions apply to all subprocesses
   103→- **OS-level enforcement**: Linux uses bubblewrap, macOS uses Seatbelt sandbox
   104→- **Security benefits**: Protection against prompt injection, data exfiltration, malicious downloads, unauthorized API calls
   105→- **Policy control**: `allowUnsandboxedCommands` setting disables dangerouslyDisableSandbox escape hatch at policy level for enterprise environments
   106→- **Limitations**: Minimal performance impact; Linux and macOS only; some tools (watchman, docker) require special configuration
   107→- **Autonomous work**: Reduces permission prompts within defined boundaries
   108→
   109→---
   110→
   111→## Output Styles
   112→
   113→**What it is**: Modifications to Claude Code's system prompt that adapt it for different use cases beyond software engineering (educational, collaborative modes)
   114→
   115→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/output-styles
   116→
   117→**Key concepts**:
   118→- **Built-in styles**: Default (efficient software engineering), Explanatory (educational insights between tasks), Learning (collaborative with TODO(human) labels)
   119→- **How they work**: Directly modify system prompt; exclude code-gen instructions for non-default styles, add custom guidance
   120→- **vs other customizations**: Output styles replace default prompt entirely (vs CLAUDE.md supplements it), affect main loop only (vs Agents handle specific tasks), "stored system prompts" (vs slash commands are "stored prompts")
   121→- **Configuration**: `/output-style` (menu), `/output-style [name]` (direct switch), `/config` menu; stored in `.claude/settings.local.json` (project level)
   122→- **Custom styles**: Create via `/output-style:new I want...`; saved as markdown with frontmatter at `~/.claude/output-styles` (user) or `.claude/output-styles` (project)
   123→- **Frontmatter options**: `keep-coding-instructions: true` to retain default code generation guidance when using custom styles
   124→
   125→---
   126→
   127→## Status Line Customization
   128→
   129→**What it is**: Customizable bottom-of-screen display similar to shell prompts (Oh-my-zsh style), updating with conversation changes
   130→
   131→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/statusline
   132→
   133→**Key concepts**:
   134→- **Setup**: `/statusline` (interactive), manual configuration via `statusLine` command in settings.json
   135→- **Display**: First line of stdout becomes status line text; supports ANSI color codes; updates max every 300ms
   136→- **Available variables**: Model (id, display_name), Workspace (current_dir, project_dir), Cost metrics (total_cost_usd, duration, lines added/removed), Session (session_id, cwd, version, output_style)
   137→- **Configuration format**: JSON with type ("command"), command path, and padding
   138→- **Implementation tips**: Keep concise (one line), use emojis/colors for scannability, use `jq` for JSON parsing, ensure executable permissions
   139→
   140→---
   141→
   142→## Cost Tracking & Usage Management
   143→
   144→**What it is**: Token consumption monitoring, usage limits, and cost optimization for Claude Code sessions
   145→
   146→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/costs
   147→
   148→**Key concepts**:
   149→- **Average costs**: $6/developer/day typical; below $12/day for 90% of users
   150→- **`/cost` command**: Session-level token statistics (total cost, API duration, wall-clock time, code changes); not intended for Claude Max/Pro subscribers
   151→- **`/usage` command**: Plan usage limits and rate limit status for subscription plans
   152→- **Budget controls**: `--max-budget-usd` flag sets spending limit per session (SDK/headless mode)
   153→- **Rate limit recommendations**: 200k-300k TPM for small teams (1-5 users), scaling down to 10k-15k TPM for 500+ user organizations
   154→- **Plan management**: Workspace spend limits via Claude Console (Admin role required); historical usage reporting; automatic "Claude Code" workspace creation
   155→- **Cost optimization**: Auto-compaction at 95% capacity, specific queries, task breakdown, clearing history between sessions
   156→
   157→---
   158→
   159→## Attribution Setting
   160→
   161→**What it is**: Configuration to customize commit and PR bylines for Claude-generated content
   162→
   163→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings
   164→
   165→**Key concepts**:
   166→- New `attribution` setting replaces deprecated `includeCoAuthoredBy`
   167→- More flexible control over how Claude's contributions are credited
   168→- Allows customizing or disabling the Co-Authored-By line
   169→- Separate configuration for commits (using git trailers) and pull requests (plain text)
   170→
   171→**Configuration**:
   172→```json
   173→{
   174→  "attribution": {
   175→    "commit": "Generated with Claude Code\n\nCo-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>",
   176→    "pr": "Generated with Claude Code"
   177→  }
   178→}
   179→```
   180→
   181→---
   182→
   183→## Language Setting
   184→
   185→**What it is**: Configure Claude's preferred response language
   186→
   187→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings
   188→
   189→**Key concepts**:
   190→- Set `language` in settings.json to specify preferred response language
   191→- Examples: `"japanese"`, `"spanish"`, `"french"`
   192→- Claude will respond in this language by default
   193→- Useful for international teams or non-English workflows
   194→
   195→**Configuration**:
   196→```json
   197→{
   198→  "language": "japanese"
   199→}
   200→```
   201→
   202→---
   203→
   204→## respectGitignore Setting
   205→
   206→**What it is**: Control whether @ file picker respects .gitignore patterns
   207→
   208→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings
   209→
   210→**Key concepts**:
   211→- When `true` (default), files matching `.gitignore` patterns are excluded from `@` file suggestions
   212→- Set to `false` to include all files regardless of gitignore status
   213→- Per-project configuration available
   214→
   215→**Configuration**:
   216→```json
   217→{
   218→  "respectGitignore": false
   219→}
   220→```
   221→
   222→---
   223→
   224→## showTurnDuration Setting
   225→
   226→**What it is**: Configuration option to hide turn duration messages
   227→
   228→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings
   229→
   230→**Key concepts**:
   231→- Setting to control display of turn duration messages (e.g., "Cooked for 1m 6s")
   232→- Set to `false` to hide these messages
   233→- Helps reduce visual clutter for users who don't need timing info
   234→- Defaults to `true`
   235→
   236→**Configuration**:
   237→```json
   238→{
   239→  "showTurnDuration": false
   240→}
   241→```
   242→
   243→---
   244→
   245→## plansDirectory Setting
   246→
   247→**What it is**: Customize where plan files are stored
   248→
   249→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings
   250→
   251→**Key concepts**:
   252→- Customize the directory where plan files are saved
   253→- Path is relative to project root
   254→- Default: `~/.claude/plans`
   255→
   256→**Configuration**:
   257→```json
   258→{
   259→  "plansDirectory": "./plans"
   260→}
   261→```
   262→
   263→---
   264→
   265→## Auto MCP Tool Search
   266→
   267→**What it is**: Automatic threshold-based tool search that activates when MCP tool definitions exceed context budget
   268→
   269→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/mcp#scale-with-mcp-tool-search
   270→
   271→**Key concepts**:
   272→- Automatically enables when MCP tool descriptions exceed 10% of context window (default)
   273→- Controlled via `ENABLE_TOOL_SEARCH` environment variable
   274→- Values: `auto` (default 10%), `auto:N` (custom threshold %), `true` (always on), `false` (disabled)
   275→- MCP tools are deferred and loaded on-demand instead of preloaded
   276→- Only works with models supporting `tool_reference` blocks (Sonnet 4+, Opus 4+)
   277→- Can also be disabled via `disallowedTools` setting by denying the MCPSearch tool
   278→
   279→**Configuration**:
   280→```bash
   281→ENABLE_TOOL_SEARCH=auto:5 claude  # Custom 5% threshold
   282→```
   283→
   284→---
   285→
   286→## Ctrl-G External Editor
   287→
   288→**What it is**: Keyboard shortcut to edit prompts in system's configured text editor
   289→
   290→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/interactive-mode
   291→
   292→**Key concepts**:
   293→- Press Ctrl-G to open current prompt in external editor
   294→- Useful for composing long or complex prompts
   295→- Uses $EDITOR or $VISUAL environment variables
   296→
   297→**Expected workflow**:
   298→1. Start typing prompt in Claude Code
   299→2. Press Ctrl-G to open in editor
   300→3. Compose/edit in full editor (Vim, VS Code, nano, etc.)
   301→4. Save and close editor
   302→5. Content returns to Claude Code prompt
   303→
   304→---
   305→
   306→## File Read Token Limit
   307→
   308→**What it is**: Override default token limit for file reads
   309→
   310→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings
   311→
   312→**Key concepts**:
   313→- `CLAUDE_CODE_FILE_READ_MAX_OUTPUT_TOKENS` environment variable
   314→- Overrides the default token limit for file reads
   315→- Useful when you need to read larger files in full
   316→- Set before starting Claude Code session
   317→
   318→**Configuration**:
   319→```bash
   320→export CLAUDE_CODE_FILE_READ_MAX_OUTPUT_TOKENS=50000
   321→claude
   322→```
   323→
   324→---
   325→
   326→## Tools Interactive Mode Flag
   327→
   328→**What it is**: CLI flag to control tool availability in interactive mode
   329→
   330→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/cli-reference
   331→
   332→**Key concepts**:
   333→- `--tools` flag controls which tools are available in interactive mode
   334→- Useful for restricting capabilities in specific contexts
   335→- Can be combined with permission settings for fine-grained control
   336→
   337→**Configuration**:
   338→```bash
   339→claude --tools Read,Grep,Glob
   340→```
   341→
   342→---
   343→
   344→## Release Channel Toggle
   345→
   346→**What it is**: Configuration option to select update channel (stable vs latest)
   347→
   348→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings
   349→
   350→**Key concepts**:
   351→- `autoUpdatesChannel` setting in settings.json
   352→- `stable` channel (about one week old, skips major regressions) vs `latest` (default, most recent release)
   353→- Toggle via `/config` command or settings.json
   354→- Helps balance new features vs stability
   355→
   356→**Configuration**:
   357→```json
   358→{
   359→  "autoUpdatesChannel": "stable"
   360→}
   361→```
   362→
   363→---
   364→
   365→## Customizable Spinner Verbs
   366→
   367→**What it is**: Setting to customize the spinner verb text shown during operations
   368→
   369→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/settings
   370→
   371→**Key concepts**:
   372→- **Setting name**: `spinnerVerbs` in settings.json
   373→- **Modes**: `append` (add to default verbs) or `replace` (completely replace defaults)
   374→- **Default verbs**: "Thinking", "Cooking", etc.
   375→- **Customization**: Add personalized verbs for UI feedback during operations
   376→
   377→**Configuration**:
   378→```json
   379→{
   380→  "spinnerVerbs": {
   381→    "mode": "append",
   382→    "verbs": ["Pondering", "Contemplating"]
   383→  }
   384→}
   385→```
   386→
   387→---
   388→
   389→## Thinking Mode
   390→
   391→**What it is**: Enable extended thinking for complex reasoning tasks
   392→
   393→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows
   394→
   395→**Key concepts**:
   396→- Enable via Alt+T keyboard shortcut (after running `/terminal-setup`)
   397→- Toggle is sticky across sessions
   398→- Enabled by default for Opus 4.5 model
   399→- Improves performance on complex reasoning and coding tasks
   400→- Impacts prompt caching efficiency
   401→- Can be configured via `alwaysThinkingEnabled` setting
   402→- Token budget controlled by `MAX_THINKING_TOKENS` environment variable
   403→
   404→---
   405→
   406→## CLAUDE_BASH_NO_LOGIN Environment Variable
   407→
   408→**What it is**: Skip login shell initialization for faster bash command execution
   409→
   410→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings (Environment variables table)
   411→
   412→**Key concepts**:
   413→- Set `CLAUDE_BASH_NO_LOGIN=1` to skip loading .bash_profile, .profile, etc.
   414→- Trade-off: faster execution but may miss custom aliases, functions, PATH entries
   415→- Useful for simple commands, containers, or performance-critical workflows
   416→
   417→**Configuration**:
   418→```bash
   419→export CLAUDE_BASH_NO_LOGIN=1
   420→claude
   421→```
   422→
   423→---
   424→
   425→## CLAUDE_CODE_TMPDIR Environment Variable
   426→
   427→**What it is**: Override default temporary directory location
   428→
   429→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings (Environment variables table)
   430→
   431→**Key concepts**:
   432→- Introduced in v2.1.5
   433→- Set `CLAUDE_CODE_TMPDIR` to customize where Claude Code stores temporary files
   434→- Useful for systems with limited /tmp space or custom temp directory requirements
   435→- Helps manage disk space in constrained environments
   436→
   437→**Configuration**:
   438→```bash
   439→export CLAUDE_CODE_TMPDIR=/custom/tmp/path
   440→claude
   441→```
   442→
   443→---
   444→
   445→## CLAUDE_CODE_DISABLE_BACKGROUND_TASKS Environment Variable
   446→
   447→**What it is**: Disable all background task functionality
   448→
   449→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings (Environment variables table)
   450→
   451→**Key concepts**:
   452→- Set `CLAUDE_CODE_DISABLE_BACKGROUND_TASKS=1` to disable background tasks
   453→- Disables `run_in_background` parameter on Bash and subagent tools
   454→- Disables auto-backgrounding of long-running commands
   455→- Disables Ctrl+B backgrounding shortcut
   456→- Useful for environments where background execution is problematic
   457→
   458→**Configuration**:
   459→```bash
   460→export CLAUDE_CODE_DISABLE_BACKGROUND_TASKS=1
   461→claude
   462→```
   463→
   464→---
   465→
   466→## CLAUDE_CODE_HIDE_ACCOUNT_INFO Environment Variable
   467→
   468→**What it is**: Hide personal account information from Claude Code UI
   469→
   470→**Documentation**: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings (Environment variables table)
   471→
   472→**Key concepts**:
   473→- Set `CLAUDE_CODE_HIDE_ACCOUNT_INFO=1` to hide email address and organization name
   474→- Replaces IS_DEMO environment variable for broader use cases
   475→- Useful when streaming, recording, or presenting Claude Code sessions
   476→- Helps protect privacy in public demonstrations
   477→
   478→**Configuration**:
   479→```bash
   480→export CLAUDE_CODE_HIDE_ACCOUNT_INFO=1
   481→claude
   482→```
   483→
   484→---
   485→
   486→## CLAUDE_CODE_ENABLE_TASKS Environment Variable
   487→
   488→**What it is**: Toggle between the new task management system and the previous TODO list
   489→
   490→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/settings
   491→
   492→**Key concepts**:
   493→- Set `CLAUDE_CODE_ENABLE_TASKS=false` to revert to previous TODO list instead of task tracking system
   494→- Default is `true` (new task management system enabled)
   495→- Provides fallback for users experiencing issues with the new task system
   496→- Task system provides dependency tracking, TaskCreate/TaskUpdate/TaskGet/TaskList tools
   497→
   498→**Configuration**:
   499→```bash
   500→CLAUDE_CODE_ENABLE_TASKS=false claude
   501→```
   502→
   503→---
   504→
   505→## --add-dir CLI Flag
   506→
   507→**What it is**: Add additional working directories for Claude to access
   508→
   509→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/cli-reference
   510→
   511→**Key concepts**:
   512→- Add additional working directories beyond the current working directory
   513→- Validates each path exists as a directory before accepting
   514→- Supports loading CLAUDE.md files from additional directories
   515→- Useful for monorepos or projects with multiple related directories
   516→
   517→**Configuration**:
   518→```bash
   519→claude --add-dir ../apps ../lib
   520→```
   521→

content.content:
1→# Workflows
     2→
     3→Productivity features, keyboard shortcuts, and workflow automation in Claude Code.
     4→
     5→**Last updated**: 2026-02-01
     6→
     7→---
     8→
     9→## Interactive Mode & Keyboard Shortcuts
    10→
    11→**What it is**: Terminal interface controls for navigation, editing, and workflow management with extensive keyboard shortcuts
    12→
    13→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/interactive-mode
    14→
    15→**Key concepts**:
    16→- **General controls**: Ctrl+C (interrupt), Ctrl+D (exit), Ctrl+G (external editor), Ctrl+L (clear screen), Ctrl+O (toggle verbose/transcript), Ctrl+R (history search), Ctrl+V/Alt+V (paste images), Shift+Tab/Alt+M (permission modes), Ctrl+T (toggle task list)
    17→- **Multiline entry**: `\` + Enter, Option+Enter (macOS), Shift+Enter (after /terminal-setup)
    18→- **Quick commands**: `#` (add to memory), `/` (slash commands), `!` (direct bash), `@` (file autocomplete)
    19→- **Vim mode**: Standard navigation (h/j/k/l, w, b, f, t) and editing (dd, cc, x) with Esc mode switching; expanded motions for improved navigation; arrow key history navigation when cursor at input boundaries
    20→- **Command history**: Per-directory storage with Ctrl+R interactive search and highlighting
    21→- **Background tasks**: Ctrl+B to run long processes asynchronously with output buffering via TaskOutput tool; unified backgrounding for bash commands and agents
    22→- **Bash mode**: `!` prefix bypasses Claude's interpretation while maintaining conversation context; supports history-based autocomplete (type partial command and press Tab to complete from previous `!` commands in current project)
    23→- **Kill ring**: Ctrl-Y yanks most recent deletion, Alt-Y cycles through older deletions
    24→- **Model switching**: Alt+P (Linux/Windows) or Option+P (macOS) to switch models mid-prompt
    25→- **Thinking toggle**: Alt+T to enable/disable extended thinking mode (requires /terminal-setup); sticky across sessions
    26→- **Slash command autocomplete**: Works anywhere in input, not just at the beginning
    27→
    28→---
    29→
    30→## Customizable Keyboard Shortcuts
    31→
    32→**What it is**: Configure keybindings per context, create chord sequences, and personalize Claude Code workflow
    33→
    34→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/keybindings
    35→
    36→**Key concepts**:
    37→- **Configuration**: Run `/keybindings` to create or open `~/.claude/keybindings.json`; changes auto-detected without restart
    38→- **Contexts**: Bindings apply to specific contexts (Global, Chat, Autocomplete, Confirmation, Transcript, HistorySearch, Task, etc.)
    39→- **Actions**: Follow `namespace:action` format (e.g., `chat:submit`, `app:toggleTodos`)
    40→- **Keystroke syntax**: Modifiers use `+` separator (ctrl+k, shift+tab, meta+p); chords are space-separated (ctrl+k ctrl+s)
    41→- **Special keys**: escape/esc, enter/return, tab, space, up/down/left/right, backspace/delete
    42→- **Uppercase letters**: Standalone uppercase implies Shift (K = shift+k); with modifiers treated as stylistic (ctrl+K = ctrl+k)
    43→- **Unbinding**: Set action to `null` to unbind default shortcut
    44→- **Reserved shortcuts**: Ctrl+C (interrupt) and Ctrl+D (exit) cannot be rebound
    45→- **Terminal conflicts**: Ctrl+B (tmux prefix - press twice), Ctrl+A (screen prefix), Ctrl+Z (Unix suspend)
    46→- **Vim mode interaction**: Keybindings handle component-level actions; vim mode handles text input level; Escape in vim switches modes instead of triggering chat:cancel
    47→- **Validation**: Run `/doctor` to see keybinding warnings
    48→
    49→**Available contexts**:
    50→- Global, Chat, Autocomplete, Settings, Confirmation, Tabs, Help, Transcript
    51→- HistorySearch, Task, ThemePicker, Attachments, Footer, MessageSelector
    52→- DiffDialog, ModelPicker, Select, Plugin
    53→
    54→**Common actions by context**:
    55→- **Global**: app:interrupt, app:exit, app:toggleTodos, app:toggleTranscript
    56→- **Chat**: chat:submit, chat:cancel, chat:cycleMode, chat:modelPicker, chat:thinkingToggle, chat:externalEditor, chat:stash, chat:imagePaste
    57→- **Autocomplete**: autocomplete:accept, autocomplete:dismiss, autocomplete:previous, autocomplete:next
    58→- **Confirmation**: confirm:yes, confirm:no, confirm:cycleMode, confirm:toggleExplanation
    59→- **History**: history:search, history:previous, history:next
    60→
    61→---
    62→
    63→## Task Management System
    64→
    65→**What it is**: Enhanced task system with dependency tracking and tools for creating, updating, and querying tasks
    66→
    67→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/settings (Environment variables), https://code.claude.com/docs/en/interactive-mode (Task list section)
    68→
    69→**Key concepts**:
    70→- **Core tools**: TaskCreate (create tasks with dependencies), TaskUpdate (update status/dependencies/details), TaskGet (retrieve full task details), TaskList (list all tasks with status)
    71→- **Task dependencies**: Tasks can specify dependencies on other tasks; helps Claude organize complex multi-step work
    72→- **Persistence**: Tasks persist across context compactions and sessions
    73→- **Task list view**: Press Ctrl+T to toggle task list display; shows up to 10 tasks at a time with status indicators (pending, in progress, complete); dynamically adjusts visible items based on terminal height
    74→- **Shared task lists**: Set `CLAUDE_CODE_TASK_LIST_ID` environment variable to share a task list across sessions using named directory in `~/.claude/tasks/`
    75→- **Management**: Ask Claude directly to "show me all tasks" or "clear all tasks" for full list or cleanup
    76→- **Task deletion**: Tasks can be deleted via the `TaskUpdate` tool
    77→
    78→**Expected workflow**:
    79→1. Claude creates tasks with dependencies using TaskCreate
    80→2. Updates task status as work progresses with TaskUpdate
    81→3. Queries task details when needed with TaskGet
    82→4. Lists all tasks and their relationships with TaskList
    83→5. View task status in terminal with Ctrl+T toggle
    84→
    85→**Configuration for shared tasks**:
    86→```bash
    87→CLAUDE_CODE_TASK_LIST_ID=my-project claude
    88→```
    89→
    90→---
    91→
    92→## Checkpointing & Rewind
    93→
    94→**What it is**: Automatic file state tracking with ability to rewind conversation and/or code changes to previous points
    95→
    96→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/checkpointing
    97→
    98→**Key concepts**:
    99→- **Automatic tracking**: Every user prompt creates a checkpoint; persists across sessions
   100→- **Access**: Press Escape twice or type `/rewind` to open restoration menu
   101→- **Three restoration options**: Conversation only (keeps code), Code only (keeps conversation), Both (full rewind)
   102→- **Use cases**: Experiment with implementations, recover from bugs, iterate while maintaining stable states
   103→- **Limitations**: Does not track Bash command modifications (rm, mv, cp), external file changes, or concurrent session edits
   104→- **Automatic cleanup**: Checkpoints clean up after 30 days (configurable)
   105→- **Complementary to Git**: Designed for quick session-level recovery, not replacement for version control
   106→
   107→---
   108→
   109→## Git Workflow Automation
   110→
   111→**What it is**: Standardized patterns for commit creation and pull request workflows with safety checks
   112→
   113→**Key concepts**:
   114→- Uses Conventional Commits format: `type(scope): subject`
   115→- Automatic co-authoring with Claude
   116→- Multiple safety checks and git best practices
   117→
   118→**Commit creation workflow**:
   119→1. Run `git status`, `git diff`, `git log` **in parallel** to understand context
   120→2. Analyze all staged changes and draft commit message
   121→3. Validate commit message follows conventions (type, scope, subject)
   122→4. Add untracked files, create commit with heredoc format, run `git status` after
   123→5. If pre-commit hook modifies files, verify safety to amend (authorship check, not pushed)
   124→
   125→**PR creation workflow**:
   126→1. Run `git status`, `git diff`, check remote tracking **in parallel**
   127→2. Run `git log` and `git diff [base-branch]...HEAD` to understand full branch history
   128→3. Analyze **all commits** in branch (not just latest)
   129→4. Create PR with format: Summary (1-3 bullets), Test plan (checklist), Claude attribution
   130→5. Session automatically links to PR when created via `gh pr create`
   131→
   132→**Safety protocols**:
   133→- Never update git config
   134→- Never force push to main/master (warn if requested)
   135→- Never skip hooks (--no-verify) unless explicitly requested
   136→- Only amend commits if: (1) user explicitly requested OR (2) adding pre-commit edits
   137→- Always check authorship before amending: `git log -1 --format='%an %ae'`
   138→- Never commit unless explicitly asked
   139→
   140→---
   141→
   142→## PR Review Status Indicator
   143→
   144→**What it is**: Display of pull request review status in the prompt footer showing current branch's PR state
   145→
   146→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/interactive-mode
   147→
   148→**Key concepts**:
   149→- **Display location**: Clickable PR link in footer (e.g., "PR #446") with colored underline
   150→- **Color meanings**: Green (approved), Yellow (pending review), Red (changes requested), Gray (draft), Purple (merged)
   151→- **Interaction**: Cmd+click (Mac) or Ctrl+click (Windows/Linux) to open PR in browser
   152→- **Auto-update**: Status updates automatically every 60 seconds
   153→- **Requirements**: Requires `gh` CLI installed and authenticated (`gh auth login`)
   154→
   155→---
   156→
   157→## Parallel Execution
   158→
   159→**What it is**: Concurrent execution of multiple independent tool calls or subagents in a single message for efficiency
   160→
   161→**Key concepts**:
   162→- Claude sends multiple independent tool calls in one message when safe to do so
   163→- User can request "run agents in parallel" for concurrent subagent execution
   164→- Each parallel call executes concurrently; all must complete before Claude continues
   165→- Critical constraint: Never parallelize dependent operations (e.g., Read before Edit)
   166→
   167→**Common patterns**:
   168→- **Git pre-commit**: `git status`, `git diff`, `git log` together
   169→- **Multi-file reads**: Several `Read` calls for different files
   170→- **Parallel agents**: `code-reviewer` + `test-runner` simultaneously
   171→- **Codebase search**: Multiple `Grep` with different patterns
   172→
   173→**Constraints**:
   174→- Never use placeholders or guess parameters - wait for actual values
   175→- Sequential dependencies require sequential calls
   176→- Results from all calls needed before continuing
   177→
   178→---
   179→
   180→## Background Agent Support
   181→
   182→**What it is**: Ability for agents to run in the background while you continue working, with asynchronous message passing
   183→
   184→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/sub-agents
   185→
   186→**Key concepts**:
   187→- Agents can now run in background while user continues working
   188→- Agents and bash commands can run asynchronously and send messages to wake up the main agent
   189→- Enables true parallel workflows with human and agent working simultaneously
   190→- Ctrl+B works for both bash commands and agents
   191→- Disable all background task functionality with `CLAUDE_CODE_DISABLE_BACKGROUND_TASKS=1`
   192→- **Pre-launch permissions**: Background agents prompt for tool permissions before launching, reducing mid-execution permission failures
   193→- **MCP tools not available**: Background subagents cannot use MCP tools
   194→
   195→**Expected behavior**:
   196→- Start an agent task that runs in background
   197→- Continue typing/working on other tasks
   198→- Agent can send messages to notify main agent when done
   199→- Results become available when background work completes
   200→
   201→**Use cases**:
   202→- Long-running analysis tasks
   203→- Test suites running while implementing next feature
   204→- Documentation generation in background
   205→- Complex search/exploration while coding
   206→
   207→---
   208→
   209→## Named Sessions
   210→
   211→**What it is**: Ability to name conversation sessions for easier resumption and organization
   212→
   213→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/common-workflows
   214→
   215→**Key concepts**:
   216→- Use `/rename` to name current session
   217→- Use `/resume <name>` in REPL to resume named session
   218→- Use `claude --resume <name>` from terminal to resume
   219→- Use `claude --from-pr <number>` to resume sessions linked to a specific PR
   220→- Makes session management more intuitive than using session IDs
   221→
   222→**Workflow examples**:
   223→```bash
   224→# In Claude Code session:
   225→/rename feature-auth-refactor
   226→
   227→# Later, resume from terminal:
   228→claude --resume feature-auth-refactor
   229→
   230→# Or resume from within Claude Code:
   231→/resume feature-auth-refactor
   232→
   233→# Resume session linked to a PR:
   234→claude --from-pr 123
   235→```
   236→
   237→**Benefits**:
   238→- Human-readable session identifiers
   239→- Easy switching between work contexts
   240→- Better organization of related work
   241→- No need to remember cryptic session IDs
   242→
   243→---
   244→
   245→## /stats Command
   246→
   247→**What it is**: Visualize daily usage, session history, streaks, and model preferences
   248→
   249→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/interactive-mode
   250→
   251→**Key concepts**:
   252→- `/stats` command provides detailed usage statistics
   253→- Shows personal usage patterns and metrics
   254→- Press 'r' to cycle through date ranges (Last 7 days, Last 30 days, All time)
   255→- Includes visual graphs and tracking features
   256→
   257→**Expected metrics**:
   258→- Favorite/most-used model
   259→- Usage over time (graph)
   260→- Usage streak (consecutive days)
   261→- Session history
   262→- Possibly token counts, session counts, etc.
   263→
   264→**Usage**:
   265→```
   266→> /stats
   267→# View statistics, press 'r' to cycle date ranges
   268→```
   269→
   270→---
   271→
   272→## /config Command with Search
   273→
   274→**What it is**: Settings interface with search functionality for finding specific settings
   275→
   276→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/interactive-mode
   277→
   278→**Key concepts**:
   279→- `/config` opens Settings interface (Config tab)
   280→- Type to search and filter settings
   281→- Makes finding specific settings easier
   282→- Keyword-based filtering of config options
   283→
   284→**Usage**:
   285→```
   286→> /config
   287→# Type to search for settings by name or description
   288→```
   289→
   290→**Expected behavior**:
   291→- Type search terms to filter settings
   292→- Filter visible config options dynamically
   293→- Quick navigation to specific settings
   294→
   295→---
   296→
   297→## /plan Command
   298→
   299→**What it is**: Direct entry into plan mode from the prompt
   300→
   301→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/interactive-mode
   302→
   303→**Key concepts**:
   304→- Use `/plan` to enter plan mode directly
   305→- Alternative to typing "let's plan" or similar prompts
   306→- Triggers plan mode with all its features (research, questions, structured planning)
   307→- Shortcut for common workflow transition
   308→
   309→**Usage**:
   310→```
   311→> /plan
   312→# Claude enters plan mode and begins gathering requirements
   313→```
   314→
   315→---
   316→
   317→## Remote Session Management
   318→
   319→**What it is**: Commands to manage remote sessions from claude.ai
   320→
   321→**Documentation**: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/interactive-mode
   322→
   323→**Key concepts**:
   324→- `/teleport` - Resume a remote session by ID or open picker (claude.ai subscribers)
   325→- `/remote-env` - Configure remote session environment (claude.ai subscribers)
   326→- Enables seamless transition between web and CLI workflows
   327→- Sessions sync between platforms
   328→
   329→**Workflow**:
   330→1. Start work on claude.ai web interface
   331→2. Use `/teleport` in CLI to resume that session
   332→3. Continue work with full CLI capabilities
   333→4. Changes sync back to web session
   334→
   335→**Benefits**:
   336→- Work continuity across platforms
   337→- Use web for planning, CLI for execution
   338→- Access sessions from anywhere
   339→

1→# Topic Index

     6→

    74→
    75→## Cross-Theme Questions
    76→
    77→Some questions span multiple themes. Load multiple files when keywords match different categories:
    78→
    79→- "How do skills work with MCP servers?" -> core-features.md (both topics)
    80→- "Should I use a skill or subagent for this?" -> decision-guide.md + core-features.md
    81→- "What permissions does my MCP server need?" -> core-features.md + configuration.md
    82→- "How do I configure thinking mode?" -> configuration.md + workflows.md
    83→- "What keyboard shortcuts are available?" -> workflows.md
    84→- "How do I customize keyboard shortcuts?" -> workflows.md (Customizable Keyboard Shortcuts section)
    85→- "How do skill hooks work?" -> core-features.md (skills and hooks sections)
    86→- "How does Auto MCP Tool Search work?" -> configuration.md + core-features.md (MCP section)
    87→- "How do I manage tasks?" -> workflows.md (task management system)
    88→- "How do I write effective prompts?" -> best-practices.md
    89→- "When should I use /clear?" -> best-practices.md + workflows.md
    90→- "How do I use Claude in Chrome?" -> integrations.md
    91→- "How do I resume remote sessions?" -> integrations.md (VS Code) + workflows.md
    92→- "How do I add multiple directories?" -> configuration.md (--add-dir flag)
    93→- "How do I resume a session by PR?" -> workflows.md (Named Sessions)
    94→
    95→## File Purposes
    96→
    97→| File | Primary Use |
    98→|------|-------------|
    99→| `core-features.md` | "How does X work?" for fundamental features |
   100→| `configuration.md` | "How do I configure/customize X?" |
   101→| `integrations.md` | IDE and platform-specific questions |
   102→| `workflows.md` | Productivity and workflow optimization |
   103→| `decision-guide.md` | "Should I use X or Y?" comparisons |
   104→| `undocumented.md` | Features not yet in official docs |
   105→| `observations.md` | User-discovered behaviors |
   106→| `sdk-behavioral-bridges.md` | Behavioral constraints from SDK docs |
   107→| `best-practices.md` | Meta-guidance: when/why to use features, failure patterns |
   108→
